[[File:FK ObiliÄ.svg|thumb|150px|left|FK ObiliÄ, a second-tier division team when Arkan took it over in summer 1996 won the FR Yugoslavia top league in 1997â98 season]]
 
In the postwar period after the [[Dayton agreement]] was signed, Arkan returned to his interests in sport and private business. The Serb Volunteer Guard was officially disbanded in April 1996 with the threat to be reactivated in case of war emergency. In June of that year he took over a second division soccer team [[FK ObiliÄ Belgrade|FK ObiliÄ]] which he soon turned into a top caliber club, even winning the [[First League of FR Yugoslavia 1997-98|1997/98]] [[Serbian Superliga|Yugoslav league]] championship. According to a book by [[Franklin Foer]], ''[[How Soccer Explains the World|How Football Explains the World: An Unlikely Theory of Globalization]]'', Arkan threatened players on opposing teams if they scored against [[FK ObiliÄ Belgrade|ObiliÄ]].
In the postwar period after the [[Dayton agreement]] was signed, Arkan returned to his interests in sport and private business. The Serb Volunteer Guard was officially disbanded in April 1996 with the threat to be reactivated in case of war emergency. In June of that year he took over a second division soccer team [[FK ObiliÄ Belgrade|FK ObiliÄ]] which he soon turned into a top caliber club, even winning the [[First League of FR Yugoslavia 1997-98|1997/98]] [[Serbian Superliga|Yugoslav league]] championship. According to a book by [[Franklin Foer]], ''[[How Soccer Explains the World|How Football Explains the World: An Unlikely Theory of Globalization]]'', Arkan threatened players on opposing teams if they scored against [[FK ObiliÄ Belgrade|ObiliÄ]].
